history.content: You can search through Piazza for longer responses I/other people have written, but the tl;dr is P/NP all of them or take them all graded, but def don't try taking some major requirements graded and others P/NP. It's worth noting this is the advice I've received from all the professors I've talked to/whose opinions I've heard about this

You can search through Piazza for longer responses I/other people have written, but the tl;dr is P/NP all of them or take them all graded, but def don't try taking some major requirements graded and others P/NP

children.subject: Just an FYI to people reading this, this goes against everything I've heard professors/academic sources say. This includes what the Berkeley Academic Senate published about selectively PNPing on their website, what professors have said (see Prof. Shewchuk's thoughts on 189 piazza) about CS grad schools, and in general logically (why would you PNP something if your grade >= what the grad schools would interpolate?). Please don't spread your own thoughts on this unless you have a reputable source to back it up, as what makes sense logically is often not the case.
Vanshaj's comments are perfectly in line with what Prof. Sahai has stated on 70 piazza about the CS grad schools.

Well, see Berkeley's view on it here. https://academic-senate.berkeley.edu/issues/coronavirus/student-qa-grading-spring-semester-2020#a3. 

"Fourth, we believe that taking a mixture of graded and P/NP classes is especially ill-advised, since graduate schools and employers will almost certainly judge that you took letter grades for the classes that you did well in and P/NP grades for the classes in which you performed poorly (e.g., did C work)."

Fact is, Professor Sahai has one view that may not necessarily reflect what other professors think. Better to not selectively PNP and not take the risk, especially when whatever decision you make now is final.
Professor Sahai did say specifically about CS 70 performance getting replaced by other courses (like EECS 126), but some courses have no analogue (pretty much all upper divs).

Prof. Ranade (from 127) also said the same thing about P/NPing some classes and taking a letter grade in others being fine.

IMO it doesn’t make much sense to say you have to either P/NP all or letter grade all. Let’s say that grad schools for some reason would look negatively on people who do a mix of P/NP and letter grades. If this were the case, why wouldn’t they look down on P/NPing everything as well, knowing that letter grades were an option at Berkeley? If it’s because they would interpret all P/NPs as the student having a rough semester due to COVID, and be more lenient about that, isn’t it possible that some students legitimately struggled this semester, but still managed to do well in some classes, and want to make that known through a letter grade? That’s a totally reasonable thing to do and I think any grad school that is okay with all P/NPs should be okay with some P/NPs, some letter grades as well.

I respectfully disagree with the student answer. I think taking some classes P/NP and others graded doesn't pose a problem, particularly with regards to grad schools and future prospects. If you perform consistently throughout college (which I strongly believe you're capable of doing), if you only take those classes for a grade this semester where your performance lines up with your general performance, then grad schools and employers are more likely to interpolate your performance in the classes you take P/NP. These are bizarre times, and if you do well in any of your classes, you shouldn't be afraid to show it just because you didn't do so well in other classes. If your circumstances allow it, it should be completely fine to use the P/NP option for some classes and take others graded.

Disclaimer: There are just my thoughts on P/NPing some courses as opposed to all of them, and do not necessarily reflect what Professors might have to say about the topic.

I don't think it will matter much in the long run if you P/NP some during these bizarre times. Courses are structured that workload comes in waves, and you may find yourself doing better in some courses whose workloads coincide with periods where you felt relatively settled and in control of your environment. Other courses' heaviest work weeks may have come at a time when you might have been most affected mentally, physically etc. due to the pandemic directly or indirectly, and thus, this may have led you to perform more poorly in those weeks. Given this (realistic) model, it should be acceptable to P/NP a course where you think you were not able to do as well as you could have in a normal semester, while being able to take what you can for a grade because you think that your grade truly reflects your understanding of the course material. Everyone's circumstances are unique in these times, and this coupled with the fact that different courses have different timelines makes the suggestion that everyone P/NP everything (or take everything for a grade) a crass one-size-fits-all solution. 

Finally, I think that grad schools in general will be aware of the pandemic when considering your application, given its recency and unheard of impact on all aspects of daily life, and thus will probably pay less attention to your grades for this semester.

history.content: Just wondering, if I am planning to leave the pnp option for my classes, is it better to pnp some or to pnp all of them?
history.subject: PNP all vs some
